Load the two raw CSV files that hold ‘State Rankings’ for Identity-Theft reports and for Fraud & Other reports.

Parse each file with a custom Table.parse_table routine that:  • strips commas inside quoted strings,  • splits the file into separate embedded tables, and  • stores every embedded table as a TableCsv object holding column names and rows.
Extract from each parsed file the embedded table named ‘State Rankings: Identity Theft Reports’ and ‘State Rankings: Fraud and Other Reports’.
Iterate over the rows of the identity-theft table; for every state pick out:  • the state name (row[1]),  • the total-reports column (row[2]),  • the ‘reports-per-100 K’ column (row[3]).
Derive the state’s population as  population = (reports-per-100 K) / (total reports).
Locate the matching row for the same state in the fraud/other table and pull its ‘reports-per-100 K’ value (row2[3]).
Compute a combined density for the state:  combined_density = (identity_theft_reports_per_100k + fraud_other_reports_per_100k) / population.
Keep track of the state whose combined_density is the highest; return that state name as the answer.
